channel.title: Bloomberg Politics
channel.copyright: Copyright 2025 BLOOMBERG L.P. ALL RIGHTS RESERVED

item.title: Democrats Lose Challenge to Trump’s Order on Election Commission
item.description: The Democratic Party’s governing body lost its legal challenge to an executive order by President Donald Trump that it said would eliminate the bipartisan nature of the Federal Elections Commission and shift authority to the White House.
item.dc:creator: Robert Burnson

item.title: Trump Signs Order Doubling US Steel, Aluminum Tariffs to 50%
item.description: President Donald Trump has raised steel and aluminum tariffs to 50% from 25%, following through on a pledge to boost US import taxes to help domestic manufacturers.
item.dc:creator: Josh Wingrove

media:content.media:description: A crane moves a roll of coiled steel at a steel plant in Hamilton, Ontario. Photographer: James MacDonald/Bloomberg

item.title: South Korea’s Lee Kicks Off Presidency With Vow to Fix Economy
item.description: South Korea’s newly elected President Lee Jae-myung took office with a pledge to revive the nation’s tariff-hit economy and seek dialogue with North Korea to diffuse tensions on the Korean Peninsula.
item.dc:creator: Soo-Hyang Choi, Hyonhee Shin

media:content.media:description: Lee Jae-myung at the National Assembly in Seoul on June 4.

item.title: Merz Has Courted and Criticized Trump From Afar. Now They Meet
item.description: After weeks of preparation, the new German chancellor faces his biggest test yet.
item.dc:creator: Arne Delfs

media:content.media:description: Friedrich Merz will travel to Washington for his inaugural meeting with Trump on June 5.

item.title: UK Confronts Hard Reality of Rebuilding Its Military Prowess
item.description: Years of underinvestment, botched contracts and poor recruitment have hollowed out what was once a superpower.
item.dc:creator: Ellen Milligan, Caroline Hepker

media:content.media:description: The factory floor at BAE System’s manufacturing site in Washington, northeast England.

item.title: Pentagon Wants to Delay Navy’s Next-Gen Fighter to Focus on F-47
item.description: The Pentagon wants to give priority to the Air Force’s F-47 stealth fighter over Navy plans to develop its own next-generation jet, arguing that pursuing the two programs at the same time could delay them both.
item.dc:creator: Anthony Capaccio

media:content.media:description: A rendering of Air Force's sixth-generation fighter, the F-47. Source: US Air Force

item.title: Lagarde’s ECB Future Set for Scrutiny After WEF Job Speculation
item.description: Christine Lagarde is about to face scrutiny on her commitment to keep leading the European Central Bank, not least as she nears the milestone of having just about tamed inflation.
item.dc:creator: Jana Randow, Craig Stirling

media:content.media:description: Christine Lagarde

item.title: Philippine Vice President Duterte Questions Impeachment Trial Under New Congress
item.description: Philippine Vice President Sara Duterte has questioned whether her impeachment trial on charges that include a suspected plot to assassinate President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. can go forward when a new set of lawmakers takes office next month.
item.dc:creator: Andreo Calonzo, Cliff Harvey Venzon

media:content.media:description: Sara Duterte Photographer: Lisa Marie David/Bloomberg

item.title: Rubio Eulogizes Tiananmen Protesters as Tariffs Test Ties
item.description: US Secretary of State Marco Rubio praised pro-democracy protesters who were killed in Beijing’s bloody Tiananmen Square crackdown 36 years ago, carrying on Washington’s criticism of China’s human rights record as tariff disputes further test already frayed ties.
item.dc:creator: Alan Wong

media:content.media:description: Marco Rubio Photographer: Nathan Howard/Bloomberg

item.title: Korean Stocks Set for Bull Market, Bonds Tumble After Election
item.description: South Korea’s equity benchmark climbed and is on track to enter a bull market, after Lee Jae-myung’s widely-expected win in the presidential election ended a months-long political leadership vacuum.
item.dc:creator: Jaehyun Eom, Youkyung Lee

item.title: University of Florida President Pick Santa Ono Rejected After Republican DEI Backlash
item.description: Florida state university leaders voted to reject Santo Ono as president of the University of Florida, following Republican backlash over the former University of Michigan president’s previous support for diversity programs.
item.dc:creator: Janet Lorin, Michael Smith

media:content.media:description: Gainesville, University of Florida, campus entrance with students. (Photo by: Jeffrey Greenberg/Universal Images Group via Getty Images)

item.title: Mexico Will Ask US Government for Steel Tariff Exemption
item.description: Mexico will ask Donald Trump’s administration this week to be exempted from an increase in steel tariffs to 50%, the country’s economy minister said on Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: Alex Vasquez

media:content.media:description: View of a truck loaded with steel rolls in the Lazaro Cardenas Cargo Port, Michoacan State, Mexico on April 25, 2025. (Photo by Alfredo ESTRELLA / AFP) (Photo by ALFREDO ESTRELLA/AFP via Getty Images) Photographer: ALFREDO ESTRELLA/AFP

item.title: South Korea Elects Lee President, Capping Six Months of Chaos
item.description: Left-leaning challenger Lee Jae-myung won South Korea’s presidential election, ending three years of conservative rule in a race that was largely a verdict on his ousted predecessor’s botched attempt to revive martial law in the longstanding US ally.
item.dc:creator: Soo-Hyang Choi, Hyonhee Shin

media:content.media:description: Lee Jae-myung on June 4. Photographer: SeongJoon Cho/Bloomberg

item.title: Trump Taps Former Small Business Chief for Role Overseeing CFIUS
item.description: President Donald Trump has nominated Chris Pilkerton, the acting head of the Small Business Administration during his first term, to oversee a committee charged with screening foreign investments into the US as well as outbound investments in foreign countries, with a close eye on competition with China.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Flatley

media:content.media:description: The US Treasury Department building in Washington, DC, US, on Saturday, May 10, 2025. The legislative push for President Donald Trump's massive tax package will begin in earnest next week as key House committees consider the legislation despite lingering divisions among Republicans. Photographer: Aaron Schwartz/Bloomberg

item.title: House SALT Deal Will Have to Change, Senate Leader Thune Says
item.description: Senate Majority Leader John Thune believes the deal that led the US House to increase the maximum deduction for state and local taxes to $40,000 will have to be changed in his chamber, according to his office.
item.dc:creator: Steven T. Dennis, John Harney

media:content.media:description: Senate Majority Leader John Thune at the US Capitol in Washington, DC, on June 3.

item.title: Walmart Cuts Some Florida Jobs After Immigration Rulings
item.description: Walmart Inc. is terminating some jobs in Florida after recent Supreme Court rulings about the legal residency of migrants, the latest sign that such orders are hitting US workplaces.
item.dc:creator: Daniela Sirtori, Jaewon Kang

media:content.media:description: A Walmart store in Cromwell, Connecticut, US, on Friday, Nov. 10, 2023. Walmart Inc. is scheduled to release earnings figures on November 16. Photographer: Joe Buglewicz/Bloomberg

item.title: China’s Top Diplomat Urges US to Put Relations on ‘Right Track’
item.description: Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi used his first meeting with new US Ambassador David Perdue to complain about recent actions by Washington, underscoring a downturn in relations between the world’s two biggest economies.
item.dc:creator: Philip Glamann, Fran Wang

media:content.media:description: Wang Yi, right, shakes hands with David Perdue in Beijing on June 3.

item.title: Penn Wins Dismissal of Antisemitism Suit by Jewish Students
item.description: A federal judge dismissed a lawsuit against University of Pennsylvania filed by Jewish students over antisemitism, ruling they failed to show the Ivy League school engaged in intentional discrimination.
item.dc:creator: David Voreacos

media:content.media:description: Students on the University of Pennsylvania campus in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, US, on Friday, Dec. 8, 2023. Penn was sued by a pair of students who claim the campus was a hotbed of antisemitism even before Hamas attacked Israel on Oct. 7.

item.title: UK Could Miss 2030 Clean Power Goal, Parliament Committee Warns
item.description: The UK’s goal of a clean power grid by 2030 is in danger of slipping out of reach as planning delays and infrastructure bottlenecks challenge the government.
item.dc:creator: Eamon Farhat

media:content.media:description: An electricity pylon, offshore wind turbines and solar panels at Cleve Hill Solar Park near Faversham, UK, on Wednesday, Oct. 23, 2024. Mytilineos has undertaken the engineering, procurement and construction of this solar park, that will produce 373.922 GWh of renewable electricity per year, enough to meet the needs of over 100,000 UK homes.

item.title: Reeves Fights Back Against Cuts Narrative With UK Building Blitz
item.description: Chancellor of the Exchequer Rachel Reeves will detail hundreds of billions of pounds worth of projects to fix Britain’s creaking infrastructure during next week’s spending review, a crunch moment for Keir Starmer’s administration as it struggles to regain momentum after a faltering first year in power.
item.dc:creator: Joe Mayes

media:content.media:description: UK Chancellor of the Exchequer Rachel Reeves.

item.title: Outspoken South Korea Leftist Survived Stabbing on Path to Power
item.description: Lee Jae-myung, the tenacious left-leaning maverick who became South Korea’s new president Wednesday, has spent a lifetime picking himself off the canvas to fight again.
item.dc:creator: Soo-Hyang Choi

media:content.media:description: Lee Jae-myung, center left, and his wife Kim Hye-gyeong at the party’s election night event in Seoul on June 4.

item.title: Trump Revokes Biden-Era Rule on Emergency Abortions in Hospitals
item.description: The Trump administration rescinded guidance put in place by former President Joe Biden that directed US hospitals to provide abortions on an emergency basis when they’re medically necessary to stabilize patients.
item.dc:creator: Jessica Nix

media:content.media:description: Female patient hospital bed with IV RF Photographer: Sorrasak Jar Tinyo/Moment RF

item.title: US Farm Sentiment at 4-Year High as Trump Seeks Trade Deals
item.description: American farmer sentiment jumped to a four-year high, with growers betting on rising crop exports as the Trump administration pushes for more trade deals from Vietnam to Italy.
item.dc:creator: Michael Hirtzer, Erin Ailworth, Skylar Woodhouse

item.title: Mexico Vote for Top Court Shows Majority With Morena Ties
item.description: Mexico’s new Supreme Court will feature a clear majority of justices with direct ties to the country’s former leftist president or the ruling Morena party he founded, according to preliminary election results with nearly all votes counted.
item.dc:creator: Alex Vasquez, Maya Averbuch

media:content.media:description: Claudia Sheinbaum, Mexico's president, casts a ballot at a polling station during the judicial elections in Mexico City, Mexico, on Sunday, June 1, 2025. Mexican voters head to the polls on Sunday to begin picking judges in an unprecedented election that could give President Sheinbaum broad influence over a revamped judiciary, the only branch of government her party doesn't control.

item.title: Trump Asks Congress to Slash Funds for NPR, PBS and Foreign Aid
item.description: President Donald Trump asked lawmakers to cut more than $9 billion in funding for the Public Broadcasting Service, National Public Radio and foreign aid from this year’s budget, an attempt to write into law some of the so-called “DOGE cuts” initiated by Elon Musk’s Department of Government Efficiency.
item.dc:creator: Gregory Korte, Erik Wasson

media:content.media:description: The National Public Radio (NPR) headquarters in Washington, DC, US, on Monday, May 5, 2025. President Donald Trump last week ordered an end to taxpayer subsidies for National Public Radio and the Public Broadcasting Service, a longstanding goal of some Republicans who have accused the media outlets of bias.

item.title: Credit Card Swipe Fee Fight Complicates Stablecoin Bill Passage
item.description: An effort by retailers and their allies in the Senate to mandate competition to Visa Inc. and Mastercard Inc. in credit card processing has complicated efforts to swiftly pass the stablecoin bill supported by the crypto industry and President Donald Trump.
item.dc:creator: Steven T. Dennis, Paige Smith

media:content.media:description: Visa Inc. and Mastercard Inc. credit cards are arranged for a photograph in Tiskilwa, Illinois, U.S., on Tuesday, Sept. 18, 2018. Visa and Mastercard agreed to pay as much as $6.2 billion to end a long-running price-fixing case brought by merchants over card fees, the largest-ever class action settlement of an antitrust case.

item.title: Chinese Firms Brush Off US Tariff Risks With Domestic Confidence
item.description: When US President Donald Trump took aim at China with record tariffs, the country’s firms shrugged it off.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Yeo

media:content.media:description: Gantry cranes and a container ship at the Yangshan Deepwater Port in Shanghai, China, on Wednesday, May 14, 2025. China and the US agreed to temporarily lower tariffs levied against each other's products — the first major de-escalation in the trade row that was touted by US President Donald Trump as a "total reset" of bilateral ties.

item.title: White House Memo on EV Grants Sets Up Fight Over Spending Power
item.description: The White House forcefully rejected a congressional watchdog’s opinion that found the Trump administration illegally delayed funding for electric vehicle infrastructure, setting the stage for a broader constitutional clash over federal spending powers.
item.dc:creator: Gregory Korte

media:content.media:description: A Toyota Rav-4 Prime charges at a ChargePoint electric vehicle charging station in Hudson, New York, US, on Tuesday, Sept. 3, 2024. ChargePoint Holdings Inc. is scheduled to release earnings figures on September 4.

item.title: Trump Aide Hassett Reveals Coinbase Stake of at Least $1 Million
item.description: Kevin Hassett, one of President Donald Trump’s top economic officials, revealed holding a stake in Coinbase Global Inc. worth at least $1 million thanks to his work as an adviser for the US crypto exchange, according to his financial disclosure.
item.dc:creator: Bill Allison

media:content.media:description: Kevin Hassett, director of the National Economic Council, speaks to members of the media following a meeting with lawmakers at the US Capitol in Washington, DC, US, on Monday, April 28, 2025. Bessent and congressional Republicans are meeting to sketch out the plan for passing a multi-trillion tax cut in the coming weeks as polling shows that voters largely disapprove of the White House’s handling of the economy.

item.title: Ecopetrol Spying Probe Adds Fuel to Colombia Corruption Storm
item.description: Colombian prosecutors are probing an Ecopetrol SA contract tied to surveillance of the company’s own executives, turning up pressure on CEO Ricardo Roa and President Gustavo Petro.
item.dc:creator: Andrea Jaramillo

media:content.media:description: Ricardo Roa
